content.title: Natural History of Untreated Peripheral Arterial Disease
content.statement: Natural History of Untreated Peripheral Arterial Disease is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Pad that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Natural History of Untreated Peripheral Arterial Disease helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Natural History of Untreated Peripheral Arterial Disease include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Natural History of Untreated Peripheral Arterial Disease.

treatment_priorities: Cardiovascular risk reduction takes precedence over limb revascularization
Smoking cessation is mandatory for all PAD patients
Aggressive statin therapy regardless of baseline cholesterol
intervention_thresholds: Claudication alone: Medical therapy and exercise first
Lifestyle-limiting claudication: Consider intervention after medical optimization
CLTI (rest pain, tissue loss): Urgent revascularization needed

prefLabel.@value: Natural History of Peripheral Arterial Disease

definition.@value: The characteristic progression of peripheral arterial disease without intervention, marked by relatively stable limb outcomes but significantly elevated cardiovascular mortality.

presentation: Intermittent claudication with predictable walking distance
Symptom stability in most patients over time
treatment: Revascularization reserved for lifestyle limitation or CLTI

sources.source: UpToDate. (2024). Natural History of Untreated Peripheral Arterial Disease. Wolters Kluwer.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Describe the 5-year limb and survival outcomes for patients with claudication
Explain why cardiovascular risk reduction is prioritized over limb intervention
Identify predictors of progression from claudication to CLTI
Apply natural history data to patient counseling and treatment planning
clinical_pearls: The leg will survive, but the patient may not - CV mortality >> amputation risk
Only 1-3% of claudicants progress to CLTI annually
5-year mortality is 20-30%, mostly from cardiac events
Diabetics and smokers have worst progression rates
ABI <0.50 predicts higher limb event risk
